millsfield:images_texts:
Dec 7 1933.
Shanghai
Dear Panily.
Running true to form I am writing another circular letter
from the air.
This time its on a trip from Shanghai
to Peiping (Peking
Peiping, by the way,
means City of Peace of which it has very
little.
Peking means Northern Capital so when the capital was moved
Nanking the
name was changed.
All of the foreign powers had acquir-
and built embassies in Peking so they just stayed on after the
was moved and now there exists the unusual and possibly happy
circumstance of all the diplomats being located approximately 1000
miles away from the government.
We left Shanghai on schedule time at 7 a.m.
Our course is
northward across the Yangesze and the fertile delta
land where every
inch of land is cultivated,
and houses a living or dead Chinese.
There are graves everywhere but aside from those and small houses
huddled together in small villages, all the land is neatly cultivated -
Actually there
is nothing on the ground in all
China that is neat.
us south of Soochow and a line of villages which marks the route of
the grand canal, that oldest and longest of man-created waterways in
the world.
We cross the Yangtze at Nantung near which we have an
emergency landing field.
It is a beautiful day - max brilliant sun-
shine
thermometer about 60 degrees but we are warned that there is
snow at Peiping and freezing weather.
Our flight is about parallel
to the coast with the first stop 300 miles north of Shanghai at a
place called Haichow - not on many maps but its about 60 miles north
of the old mouth of the Yellow River,
which stream (often called China's
Sorrow because of the havoc caused by it in flood time) changed its
course back in 1852.
We have just passed over the old river mouth
and landed at Haichow to deliver the mail and take on a load for
Tsingtao, Tientsin and Pei ping. Our agent at Heichow tells us there
In the small village of only a few
only built of stone instead of logs.
We see similar structures
in all the towns even some of
those which have walls.
Now we are
following the China See with Isingtao 120 miles N.N.E.
That place
as you no doubt know was developed as a sort of German Hongkong.
World War came along the English and Japs besieged Tsingtao and
Japan thereafter held on to it until the Washington Conference of
1922.
Then it was turned back to China.
I have always maintained while having no pretense of being
economist,
that most progress in is the result of laziness.
does not necessarily follow that lazy people are smart but some of them
are and so they have given us all sorts of laborsaving devices.
Chinese are not lazy.
Possibly that fact accounts for their lack of
At Foochow our
station is near a large rice field.
Chinese farmer and his wife who own the field pump water from the river
on to the field by means of a treadmill which operates a chain gang of
small buckets.
The man and woman apparently spend most of their time
plodding along on that treadmill.
they were not so energetic it
seems to me they would have developed some kind of a windmill to do,
or at least help
that job.
Today I noticed flying south of Haichow
of windmill which would do the work for them.
It is constructed
like the skeleton of a large lampshade.
The diameter of the top and
bottom circles is from 20 to 30 feet.
The upper circle is supportea
connected to the lower by eight uprights
of about 10 to 15
To these uprights are fastened oblong shaped sails.
whole framework turning round on a center axis which in turn drives a
gear which carries an
endless chain of little buckets.
The whole
countryside was covered with these contraptions -
some little ones
apparently privately owned and some large
ones evidently community
At home probably some drainage district or irrigation district
be issuing bonds against them.
